b: ^Call to Action: how to enable sign language
^Cass: (Examining self in video call window) Okay, the video call is ready, how do I look? Freshly funkified hair, awesome black jacket, is the guyliner too much?
^Cass: Am I really calling it that? What's the nonbinary version of guyliner? I guess it's just 'eyeliner'...
^Cass: (Eyes light up) Or is it gayliner?
^Cass: Is it even possible to be 'too much' with Iris? Last time we spoke they looked like

s0: ^ they'd just waltzed off the intergalactic version of those old-timey variety shows
s1: ^ they'd never dream of leaving the house without wearing something sequinned
s2: ^ they just emerged fully formed from a giant vat of glitter

s0: ^ Why do I feel so tired? Oh, I was up all night thinking about...
s1: ^ God I feel so anxious. I knew I shouldn't have watched that video essay about...
s2: ^ that up last night. Why did you let yourself get into a rant about...

s0: ^Well I don't need to worry about that anymore! Soon everything is going to change for me
s1: ^ Aaargh. No, I need to focus, I can't think about this right now.

s: ^News: They're really gonna make us vote for THAT!?

Iris: ^Iris: My goodness, what a wonderful place this is! Rotherham, did you say it was called?
^Iris: Ooh I can't wait to go out and experience...

s: ^Iris: The physical embrace of another living being

g-0: ^Cass: This giant blue glowing mass that's in front of me?
^Iris: (Dismissive) It's just the place where reality ends and the void begins.
^Iris: It shouldn't be a problem, nothing's fallen into the void for years
^Iris: Best of luck, ta-ta for now!
^Cass: (Looks at the void with horror) No no no no no what have you done?

MagicSchool: ^Cass: Oh my god oh my god oh my god this is really happening
^Cass: Alright stay calm. Be cool. Just answer like a normal person.
^Cass: (handles the laptop gingerly as though defusing a bomb, trying to calm themself)
^Iris: Oh this really is FABULOUS! I knew telephony would be a hit with the humans.
^Iris: Hello, it's lovely to talk to you again ah... Cass, wasn't it? How have you been doing?
^Cass: Great thank you! I can't wait to get started.
^Iris: I'm delighted to hear that - get started with what exactly?
^Cass: Like... you're from the organisation, right? Aren't you going to train me up, teach me how to be the thing that I am supposed to be?
^Iris: I don't quite follow, but er... it seems like you expect something from me?
^Cass: I just... I thought being part of this intergalactic organisation...
^Cass: Yeah okay whatever. I thought it would be...

c-0: ^ (Embarrassed) Like the Federation in Star Trek?
^Cass: (Increasingly enthusiastic) You'd be a representative of a vast organisation that makes sure everyone who works within it is okay, and has super advanced technology
^Cass: and it trains people to be like science geniuses or brilliant leaders, and everybody travels through space to distant worlds, to boldly go where no-one has gone before!
c-1: ^Cass: (Increasingly enthusiastic) You come into my life and say "you're a wizard!" and take me to a place full of super special people, and for the first time in my life I'm somewhere I belong and I can learn to fulfil my potential, and then I go and defeat the evil sorceror and everything is better forever!
c-2: ^Cass: (Increasingly enthusiastic) Like sure I feel like an awkward misfit now, but I just need to learn how to harness my powers for good, and maybe get some cool technology from a billionaire playboy that will further enhance my abilities
^Cass: and then together we can save the planet earth when an AI goes rogue, or a bunch of space octopuses open an intergalatic portal in
g-0: ^Iris: I have no idea what you're talking about.
^Cass: I guess I thought things would get better now that I know the truth about myself

^Iris: So you learned that you're not really human, but you were put here as part of an experiment by a vast organisation beyond your knowledge or comprehension, and your first thought was "Ooh, what a fantastic opportunity for my own personal hero arc, I bet I have superpowers now?"
^Cass: Well of course it sounds silly when you put it like that.

^Iris: This job isn't going to get you anything that you don't already have. The joy of this job isn't that it gives you any amazing abilities. It's the fact that you get to observe the stuff of life!
^Iris: You get to see how the world is made in every moment. It's beautiful, but it's not something that I can give you. It's already all around you.
^Cass: (rolls eyes) So the real transdimensional superpower was

s0: ^ the friends we made along the way?

AFewGoodMen: ^Iris: I've been wondering why things are so dismal there. I don't suppose you have any insights you could share?
^... I dunno, everything? The climate, sickness, death, the economy...
^Iris: Ah yes, MONEY! So they're still doing that, are they?
^Cass: Money? Yes it's very much still a thing
^Iris: See I knew things couldn't have changed THAT much since the 1920s. Oh, the coins were so FUN!
^Iris: There were big ones and little ones and round ones and ones with lots of corners on them
^Iris: and they had faces on them, and people used to call them adorable names like "tuppence" and "dime".
^Iris: And they even had this big complex game where men would stand around in crowded rooms yelling numbers at each other.
^Iiris: BUY ME SOME G.E. AT ONE HUNDRED AND TWENTY EIGHT! TRUAX AT FIVE HUNDRED! GDEB AT ONE THOUSAND AND EIGHTY NINE!
^Cass: ... are you describing the stock market?
^Iris: YES! Are they still doing that?
^Cass: (refusing to be distracted) Why are we talking about this?
^Cass: I know you think this is all so charming or whatever, but it's different when you're here, dealing with poverty and crisis after crisis and

b: ^Cass: Why do I have to waste time here, living in a nightmare world dreamed up by a society of miserable
^Cass: Do you know how lonely it is here, to be the only one who sees that we are all wasting our time while the planet dies?

^Cass: When I first found you, I thought of you as a superior being who would show me the way to my destiny or something.

^Cass: I imagined a thousand different ways I could explain to you that I need a way out of here.

^Cass: I thought if I just said the right thing or did everything right, you'd understand and you'd get me to a world that isn't so broken.
^Cass: You realise I'm living through a mass disabling event AND climate collapse AND the global rise of fascism AND I'm doing all of this on
^Cass: AND Netflix keeps cancelling all the shows that just for a brief moment make me feel like a real human being?
^Cass: It's no wonder we have an opioid crisis. Sometimes I would give anything to just sleep like I did as a baby in my mother's arms, back when I didn't know anything.
^Iris: (viscerally disgusted) Grotesque! Surely you don't mean that? You'd rather be a BABY?
^Cass: Well no, OBVIOUSLY I wouldn't want to be a baby NOW, when nobody can even promise that there will BE a world for kids to grow old in.

AFewGoodMen: ^Iris: Oh my goodness you are SO intense. I LOVE this energy, things never get that exciting around here. But there's something I really don't understand.

s: ^News: Vox Populi, Vox Dei: Have your say about

c-0: ^Iris: If things are really so apocalyptic, why are the humans still playing their money games and making computing machines?
^Cass: I don't know... It's like we're just doing the same thing over and over again because that's just what you do.
^Cass: As if things aren't totally broken and falling apart here, as if I'm not absolutely losing my mind just watching it all crumble.

WeHaveToGoBack: ^Iris: (Enters, giddy with joy) Oh what a DAY it's been!
^Cass: (Stumbles into view, haggard with stress) Oh my god you're BACK.
^Iris: (Breezy) Ah good, I see you're still holding the fort!
^Cass: You have a giant gaping hole in reality, here in your house???
^Iris: Ha, I hardly think YOU are in a position to criticise MY housekeeping
^Cass: Housekeeping? You think this is about housekeeping?
^Cass: There isn't anything outside of this one room, it's all just that blue void!
^Iris: It's FINE, just make sure you maintain a constant mental model of the space around you and reality should continue to remain coherent
^Iris: You're a perfectly intelligent individual, I'm sure you'll have no trouble with it.

nohopeofrefuge: ^Cass: So my job is just to be? here and tell you what it's like?
^Iris: You see, it's not so hard after all is it?
^Cass: I don't know how it is where you are in that University of the Multiverse or whatever--

b:
^Cass: I bet you wake up every day knowing that all your needs will be met, with 3D printed food and no energy bills to pay

^Iris: Yes yes we all know about these primitive worlds with their finite energy and exothermal cooking methods, this is all taught in the first week of Transdimensional Anthropology 101
^Cass: I bet you swan about every night drinking magical cocktails, and your libraries are all
^Cass: and the books are living creatures, and every health problem can be solved with incantations and mystical plants

^Iris: Oh, okay, I understand. I've been in this situation before. I'm sorry, but I'm going to have to set a firm boundary here. I'm not going to help you to get hold of any drugs, be they in the form of exotic plants, liquid libations, neurotoxic gases or any other form of matter.
^Cass: I bet you live at the top of a giant
^Cass: and every day you choose a different robot exosuit to wear
^Cass: so that you can just jetpack your way to the
^ corner shop and buy yourself a carton of milk with your infinite superhero money
^Iris: Ew. You really think I would drink MILK? I'm not a monster.

nohopeofrefuge: ^Cass: It's not so easy here on earth!
^Cass: Compared to this garbage fire of a world, whatever is going on at the institute has to be like a

s: ^News: Vox Populi, Vox Dei: Have your say about

asmywillconcurdnot: ^Iris: (A look of dawning realisation crosses their face… and then fear)
^Iris: Okay… okay, I think we need to try something.
^Iris: What happens if you just… stop?
^Iris: Just stop. Just close your eyes, and let it all go. Stop trying to think things through, stop trying to be this PERSON, stop modelling the world in your mind. Just let it all go and just be?
^Cass: Mindfulness, it’s a thing people do for wellbeing I guess?
^Cass: Honestly I'm sick of being told to do it as if it's going to
^Iris: I’ve never heard of it, but it can’t possibly be that.
^Iris: Wellbeing? No, this is very dangerous, I wouldn’t recommend that anybody do this for wellbeing.
^Cass: Look I’m sure it’s not a big deal, I just don't think it's going to help. I mean I don't want to knock it if you've found it helpful
^Iris: God no, if I did it the entire fabric of reality around me would unravel. No no no I have to keep busy busy busy
^Cass: (baffled) Okay well... I guess I'll just... (Long exhale, letting tension drop in shoulders)
^Iris: (unmutes) Actually, wait, can you stand further away?
^Iris: I need to see more of you while you do this, could you take a few steps back?
^Cass: … okay … (Steps back from the laptop, and closes eyes again, dropping tension in their body)
Reality_intact: ^Iris: (Watching the screen the whole time, increasingly amazed that Cass is actually doing this)
^Cass: (holds this position for a while longer, appearing completely still and serene.)
^Iris: (gets increasingly excited by the absolute lack of any activity taking place)
^Cass: Well I'm glad YOU had a good time!
^Cass: First I was aware of my body, especially the feeling of clothing on my skin, the tags rubbing and the seams digging in.
^Cass: I felt the outline of my body on my clothes, and I felt super aware of the ways my shape feels really bad and wrong.
^Cass: Like this really basic form of gender dysphoria, my body has developed into this form that just isn’t right, and I feel like I can’t cope with all this for a minute longer.
^Cass: Then I started thinking about how I've been communicating with you, and I decided..

s: ^Cass: I'm going to moderate my language from now on

g-0: ^Cass: Then that gave way to this feeling like my body was twisting and the world was shifting sideways. My head was floating and my legs were drifting up.
^Cass: And then there was just emptiness. This deep, dark emptiness, like I’m totally alone in the world.
^Iris: (interrupts with an incongruously cheery tone) BUUUUT your body stayed together!
^Iris: All in one place and in the same form as ever!
^Iris: And the world stayed where it was, and nothing that you did or didn’t do made any difference to anything!
^Cass: (Even more baffled than before) What did you THINK was going to happen?
^Iris: I didn’t know what would happen - your arms might have unravelled like skeins of wool, your head might have dissolved into a swarm of bees, the walls could have started melting…
^Cass: And you didn’t think to warn me!?
^Cass: It didn’t feel “excellent” it felt like I was slowly dying
^Iris: I mean, technically you ARE slowly dying! But the good news is that no matter how awful you feel...
^Iris: Nothing that you personally do is affecting the basic fabric of reality!
^Iris: Because you still live in the same world as everyone around you!
^Cass: So the good news is that nothing I do matters?
^Iris: Yes, literally your thoughts and actions do not (gestures as though picking something apart with fingers) MATTER
^Cass: I just really, really don't want to be here anymore. Why did you put me here?
^Cass: If you hadn't put me in a society where I don't fit, I wouldn't need to be this

irisrants: ^Iris: Oh but I must say, this world is EXTRAORDINARY!
^Iris: I just ran outside and experienced
^ for the first time in years. I forgot how good it feels.
^Iris: All of this ridiculous beauty could only exist in a world as coherent as this one
^Iris: A world created by the random impulses of billions of deeply strange people

s: ^News: Vox Populi, Vox Dei: Have your say about

CommunicationGoals: ^Iris: (sincerely excited) Ah, this is fascinating, thank you for this very thorough report!
^Iris: I can see that we're getting off to a truly promising start.
^Iris: Oh don't be so modest. You're doing a FANTASTIC job here, you've clearly been paying very close attention.
^Iris: I did my fieldwork in the 1920s, and I had no idea WHAT was going on
^Iris: I spent FAR too much time partying. You must have adapted very well indeed.

s: ^Cass: Sorry, I'll turn my swear word filter on

g-0: ^Iris: My dear, it takes real skill to be able to navigate a complex information environment such as the one that currently exists on earth.
^Cass: It's just what you do. I wouldn't call it a skill.
^Iris: You learn far more through sheer necessity than the rest of us ever could through observation. That's the value of this research.
^Cass: So that's all this is? I have to live in this
^ up world and spend every day struggling, so that you can go off and what, write research papers about me?
^Iris: You have to take this all in context. You are in a position to understand these challenges with remarkable insight.
^Iris: You can see how a world is being recreated in every moment, and how it changes a little bit every day.
^Iris: I know it is hard to bear the reality of what is happening, but when you see it with this grounded perspective, you recognise that it's not the end of the world.
^Cass: IT LITERALLY IS THE END OF THE WORLD! The world is LITERALLY being destroyed by
^Iris: Come now, let's keep our wits about us. It's only the end of ONE world.
^Iris: It's your job to be particularly attached to this one, but perhaps it would bring you some solace to see this as just a project.

Transposition: ^Iris: So that's it then? You want me to snap my fingers and make it all go away?
^Can we have a constructive dialogue about this?
^Please just tell me what I need to do

c-0: ^ Why can't I do what you do? What makes you so much better than me that you get to live above it all?
^Iris: You simply don't understand what you're asking me to do.
^Iris: Please just listen, why won't you listen?
c-1: ^ Why do I even bother talking to you about this?
^Cass: All you do is tell me that I don't understand and I need to keep my head down and do what I've been sent here to do
^Cass: What gives you the right?! What the
^ do you even know? The last time you were here, the economy was booming and everyone believed that they'd just had the war to end all wars.
^Iris: I don't think this is really about me--
c-2: ^ person in the entire universe who can help me!
^Iris: Oh believe me, you do not want the help you really need.
^Cass: What do you know about what I need?!
^Iris: Clearly a lot more than you do!
g-0: ^Cass: Oh, so I'm the problem again am I?
^Iris: Why should YOU get to leave all of it behind and go somewhere else?
^Iris: Just because you don't fit in doesn't make you special. SURELY you know that you're not the only person feeling the way you do?
^Iris: I never felt like I belonged either. But believe me, there is a difference between longing for the acceptance of people around you who find you eccentric...
^Iris: and knowing that you will never again even have the chance to look into the eyes of the people who matter so much to you.
^Iris: Perhaps what you really need is to finally understand what it's like to sit here and just WATCH as a billion worlds just keep on turning without you.

Inspiration: ^Cass: Okay okay I get it, you're having a great time. But you HAVE to come back here.
^Cass: I think your world... I think it's coming apart without you.
^Iris: No no no, the void has been there for years!
^Cass: It's not just that, look! Look at all the
^Cass: It's getting more and more messed up as time goes on!
^Iris: You're the one who demanded a change of scene...
^Cass: I read some of the papers you have here, and I think I understand what's going on.
^Cass: You're the only person who exists in this world aren't you? There used to be a whole Institute with hundreds of academics, and a whole world around it, but it broke
^Cass: Reality broke down, piece by piece, and now this world is all you have left
^Cass: You're the only one who exists in it. You're the only one who CAN exist in it. And with you gone, it's going to stop existing
^Iris: (Horrible realisation) Oh... Yes, I should have known that would happen.
^Cass: I'm sorry Iris. I don't want you to be stuck here, any more than I want to go back over there.
^Cass: But if you don't come back here, this world is going to collapse
^Iris: And so what if it does? Every world will collapse eventually.
^Cass: Even if you don't care about what happens to me, think about what happens to all your work
^Cass: All this research, the books, the papers... Do you want it all to disappear?
^Cass: Didn't all of this mean something to you at some point?
^Iris: ... This is such a horrible mess.
^Iris: Very well, we will switch back, but listen...

s: ^Iris: I understand that you have been struggling here
^Iris: You must learn everything you can about this world...

c-0: ^Iris: It's just like something I saw back in the 70s.
^Cass: I thought you hadn't been here since the 1920s?
^Iris: I mean the 1870s. The Victoria and Albert Museum in London opened a gallery of lifesize reproductions of classical sculptures, like Michaelangelo's David.
^Iris: They took the original, covered it in layers and layers of plaster
^Iris: and then when it had set, they could gently pull pieces of that plaster away, put them back together again elsewhere, and use them as a mould
^Iris: This way you got a perfectly accurate reproduction of David's gorgeous pecs and nice little bottom.
^Iris: Ah yes, moulding! You might feel like you don't fit in, but you are still shaped around the society you are studying.
^Iris: And by understanding yourself, you can understand society as the sort of negative that you have been shaped around.
^Cass: So you're telling me I'm, like, the anti-bottom? The backwards nipple of society?
^Iris: Why did you have to make this uncomfortable?
c-1: ^Iris: I knew it was dangerous to switch places with you. Honestly, it's not a method we're supposed to ever use.
^Iris: Having you switch places with me was never going to work.
^Iris: Every world is created through the actions and figurations of the people and societies that occupy it.
^Iris: That little pocket world over there is mine. It's a reflection of me. Nobody else can hold it together but me.
c-2: ^Iris: Your job here is to understand this world by understanding yourself, and how you have been shaped by it.
g-0: ^Iris: This is the only world I know of that has remained whole, with billions of people somehow sharing the same reality.
^Iris: We have to understand why that is, if we're ever to rebuild and reconnect the other worlds.
^Iris: I can't do that work in your place, any more than you can keep reality together in mine.
^Cass: ... Could we maybe continue this very insightful discussion AFTER you've made it back here to keep your world together?
^Iris: Ah... yes. (Takes one last deep breath of fresh air)

Denouement: ^Iris: Let me just say one more thing.

Systems: ^Iris: This thing you're looking for isn't real. You think there might be another world where the systems work properly. There might be another society out there that is capable of solving its problems.
^Iris: It's not true. The point of society is not to solve problems or to function well.
^Iris: It's not your fault that you think there might be.
^Iris: The society you are studying has really only recently achieved industrialisation.
^Iris: It is perfectly natural for you to believe that society is like a machine
^Iris: ...and that if it is well-oiled and properly maintained it will work smoothly and efficiently.
^Iris: But society isn't a machine. It's an organism. It evolves by accident, and it is constantly in a state of tension
^Iris: always digesting new materials and producing excrement and running from threats.
^Iris: It's never going to feel clean, or even particularly satisfying.
^Iris: But it does feel like something. It does feel like being alive. And that's the entire job. You are there to feel what it's like.
^Cass: (Takes another long breath like when meditating earlier) Okay. I can do that.
Proof: ^Iris: I know how isolating it is to be there, living out every day knowing in your bones that you don't belong.
^Iris: But you are not alone in that feeling of being alone. There are so many people who feel the same way you do.
^Iris: Every society has its edges, just as every city has a periphery, every cell has an outer membrane, and every ocean has a shore. These edges are absolutely vital for life to flourish.
^Iris: They are the contact zones between one way of being and another. They are sites of constant change, precarity, and SO much DRAMA.
^Iris: For life to be possible anywhere, it has to be possible here.
^Iris: If anything is worth experiencing and understanding, it's this. We need people like you to understand how life flourishes in spaces like these.
^Iris: You have to live this life, if for no other reason than to prove that a life like this is liveable.
^Cass: But it doesn't-- (Stops, takes another long breath like when meditating earlier)
^Cass: It doesn't always feel very liveable. But I can keep trying.

b:
^Iris: What I said before about Michaelangelo's David, it wasn't quite true.

^Iris: I mean, not the bit about his sexy nipples, that's objective fact.

^Iris: But you're not just a plaster cast that fits around society. You're a part of it.

Others: ^Iris: Even though you feel like an outsider, you're still an intrinsic part of the whole.
^Iris: You're not really on the outside. You're woven in, one strand among all the others.
^Iris: If you leave, there will be something missing. Many people will feel your absence terribly.
^Iris: And the structure of the whole will be a little diminished because of it.
^Iris: Someone will have to come in and darn the holes that you leave behind.
^Iris: I think it's worth staying, at least for long enough to help the rest of the tapestry come together.
^Cass: But what if it doesn't come together? What if it keeps fraying more and more until it totally breaks apart?
^Iris: Then you'll hold onto whoever and whatever you can, and make things a little more stable for others.
^Cass: (Takes another long breath like when meditating earlier) Okay

oneLastCall: ^Iris: Hello again my dear, how have you been?
^ terrible! I can't wait to tell you all about it
greeting_tunnel: ^You've reached Cass who may I say is calling?

s: ^Cass: This is captain Cassie Prometheus Milton of the USS Shelley

c-0: ^(fast and tense) You're call Creach, whom I say as you are?
c-1: ^(Trying to sound casual, ends up sounding drunk) AEEOUUU

s4: ^ Video - It's time to recognise the crisis
s5: ^ Video - It's time to recognise the crisis
